spanishExample: ¡Dale eso, por favor! La mujer quiere tu ayuda.
englishTranslation: Give her that, please! The woman wants your help.

spanishExample: ¡Dale lo que tienes! Ella te ha dado sus cosas en el pasado.
englishTranslation: Give her what you have! She has given you her things in the past.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
ha: "has", "he/she/it has" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person)
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: ¡Dame eso! Si no, tienes que decirme dónde está.
englishTranslation: Give me that! If not, you have to tell me where it is.
vocabIncluded: dónde: adverb meaning "where?" in a question or implied question
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: ¡Di la verdad! Ellas te lo dieron.
englishTranslation: Tell the truth! They(f) gave it to you.
vocabIncluded: te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: ¿Cuáles tienes? Pues la verdad es que quiero todos.
englishTranslation: Which ones do you have? For the truth is I want all of them.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: ¿Por qué no me lo das ahora? Ayer me lo diste.
englishTranslation: Why don’t you give it to me now? Yesterday you gave it to me.
vocabIncluded: me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")

spanishExample: ¿Puedes darme eso?
englishTranslation: Can you give me that?

spanishExample: ¿Quiénes fueron a la fiesta?
englishTranslation: Who(plural) went to the party?

spanishExample: ¿Quieres hacerles ese favor para que te den tus cosas?
englishTranslation: Do you want to do them that favor so that they give you your things?
vocabIncluded: les: "them" as an indirect object ("to them", "for them")
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: ¿Quieres que te dé una mano con eso de vuelta?
englishTranslation: Do you want me to give you a hand with that in return?
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
darle una mano a: "give a hand to" (idiom)
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: Después, podemos decir algo.
englishTranslation: Afterwards, we can say something.

spanishExample: Dijiste que lo harías mientras estabas en casa.
englishTranslation: You said you would do it while you were at home.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
harías: "would do/make", "you would do/make" (Hacer, conditional, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Dime, ¿de verdad quieres que mi amigo te dé eso?
englishTranslation: Tell me, do you really want my friend to give you that?
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: El hombre con quien fuimos tiene una cara seria.
englishTranslation: The man whom we went with has a serious face.

spanishExample: El hombre siempre da una vuelta por su casa a esa hora.
englishTranslation: The man always goes for a walk around his house at that time.

spanishExample: El problema está en manos de tu madre.
englishTranslation: The problem is in your mother’s hands.
vocabIncluded: en manos de alguien: "in someone's hands" (idiom)

spanishExample: En mi mente, yo te di eso y no ellos.
englishTranslation: In my mind, I gave you that and not they.
vocabIncluded: te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: Es un ser muy bueno, tenemos que darle lo que quiera.
englishTranslation: He’s a very good being, we have to give him whatever he wants.
vocabIncluded: using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Estará ahí mientras haces tus cosas.
englishTranslation: She will be there while you do your things.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
estará: "will be", "he/she/it will be" (Estar, future, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Hicimos eso, lo cual no es bueno.
englishTranslation: We did that, which is not good.
vocabIncluded: lo cual: "which" without a specific noun (idiom)

spanishExample: Hoy le diré todo eso a mi querida amiga.
englishTranslation: Today I will say all of that to my dear friend(f).
vocabIncluded: a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
diré: "will say", "I will say" (Decir, future, 1st person)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: Juan u Oscar lo harán, aunque tienen que ir ahí de vuelta.
englishTranslation: Juan or Oscar will do it, even though they have to go there again.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
harán: __, they will __ (Hacer, future, 3rd person plural)
u: "or" (synonym for "o", used before a word starting with an "o" sound)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: La niña tiene ojos muy grandes.
englishTranslation: The little girl has very big eyes.

spanishExample: Le di lo que quería porque ellos siempre se lo dan.
englishTranslation: I gave him what he wanted because they always give it to him.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
"se" to mean "le" or "les", as in "se lo" or "se la"
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: Me da lo mismo porque nunca dices nada.
englishTranslation: It’s all the same to me because you never say anything.
vocabIncluded: me da lo mismo: "it's all the same to me" (idiom)

spanishExample: Me dio el suyo, lo cual fue una gran ayuda.
englishTranslation: She gave me hers(m), which was a big help.
vocabIncluded: gran: "big"/"grand" when used right before a noun (adjective)
lo cual: "which" without a specific noun (idiom)
me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")

spanishExample: Me estaban dando esas cosas cuando supe sobre ellos.
englishTranslation: They were giving me those things when I found out about them.
vocabIncluded: me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")
supe: "knew / found out", "I knew / found out" (Saber, preterite, 1st person)

spanishExample: Muchos le han dado problemas, pero tú le diste más que nadie.
englishTranslation: Many have given her trouble, but you gave her more than anyone.
vocabIncluded: han: "have", "they have" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person plural)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: No dijeron nada sobre hoy, así que podemos dar una vuelta.
englishTranslation: They didn’t say anything about today, so we can go for a walk.

spanishExample: No quiero que le diga nada al hombre.
englishTranslation: I don’t want her to say anything to the man.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
al: "to the" before a masculine noun
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: No te doy muchas cosas porque tú no me quieres dar nada.
englishTranslation: I don’t give you a lot of things because you don’t want to give me anything.
vocabIncluded: me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: Nosotras le dimos algo.
englishTranslation: We(f) gave her something.
vocabIncluded: le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: Si lo haces de esa manera, no puedo darte nada.
englishTranslation: If you do it in that manner, I can’t give you anything.

spanishExample: Si me haces ese favor, te daré esto.
englishTranslation: If you do me that favor, I’ll give this to you.
vocabIncluded: daré: "will give", "I will give" (Dar, future, 1st person)
me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: Si se lo dicen, entonces estaremos en problemas.
englishTranslation: If they say it to him, then we’ll be in trouble.
vocabIncluded: "se" to mean "le" or "les", as in "se lo" or "se la"
estaremos: "will be", "we will be" (Estar, future, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Siempre dice que quiere que le des tus cosas.
englishTranslation: He always says he wants you to give him your things.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: Sofía e Isabel tienen un corazón muy grande.
englishTranslation: Sofía and Isabel have a very big heart.
vocabIncluded: e: "and" (synonym for "y", used before a word starting with an "i" sound)

spanishExample: Solo diré que había mucha sangre en el lugar.
englishTranslation: I will only say that there was a lot of blood in the place.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
diré: "will say", "I will say" (Decir, future, 1st person)
había: "there was/were" indicating existence (Haber, imperfect, impersonal)

spanishExample: Te damos esas cosas, las cuales no son nuestras.
englishTranslation: We give you those things, which are not ours.
vocabIncluded: el cual / la cual: "which" (idiom / relative pronoun)
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: Te digo que él te dará lo que quieres.
englishTranslation: I’m telling you that he will give you what you want.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
"que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
dará: "will give", "he/she/it will give" (Dar, future, 3rd person)
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: Tendrá que darnos una mano si quiere que se lo demos.
englishTranslation: He’ll have to give us a hand if he wants us to give it to him.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
"se" to mean "le" or "les", as in "se lo" or "se la"
nos: "us" as an indirect object ("to us", "for us")
tendrá: "will have", "he/she/it will have" (Tener, future, 3rd person)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Tiene una cabeza grande, pero un cuerpo *small.*
englishTranslation: He has a big head, but a small body.

spanishExample: Tuvo *an accident* y ahora tiene un problema en su boca.
englishTranslation: He had an accident and now he has a problem in his mouth.

spanishExample: Un ser querido hará esas cosas, las cuales no serán *easy.*
englishTranslation: A loved one will do those things, which will not be easy.
vocabIncluded: el cual / la cual: "which" (idiom / relative pronoun)
hará: "will do/make", "he/she/it will do/make" (Hacer, future, 3rd person)
serán: "will be", "they will be" (Ser, future, 3rd person plural)
